ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned how to better code in Python, how to use computer science to perform data analysis, and how to apply data analysis to baseball, and to other sports/areas as a byproduct.

This course builds off YData and helps build a foundational understanding of Python and Data Science. You'll also learn the basics of baseball statistics.  You don't need YData, but it probably helps to understand the language we use. We used Astroball, a book about the 2017 Astros by Yale alum Ben Reiter, to talk about how baseball clubs use statistics.
Basic stats in Python through the use of baseball datasets.
I gained some familiarity with Python, including data wrangling and analysis, as well as object-oriented programming.
Python programming, statistical analysis techniques
a repeat of intro stats but applied to baseball. learned a lot about the sport, not as much new info for stats since I've taken intro stats previously.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course was great, all of the code needed to complete homeworks and the midterm were provided in lecture, and each problem set was helpful in facilitating the learning of the course while giving students the ability to attempt coding without being directly walked through it.

While the lecture only meets once a week, it is a very engaging and interactive few hours of class. It is evident that Professor Meyers put in quite a bit of work to make sure that our virtual classes were still classes that one could look forward to on a weekly basis. In terms of weakness, I personally believe that it would be beneficial if more of the course focused on predictive models and even some Machine Learning. However, I do understand that this course is intended to be introductory so the pace of the class was understandable.
It was a super interesting class. Tackled a lot of fun baseball questions. It does skew towards people who love baseball, and you talk a lot about the sport. But it's accessible to all.
Labs well structured and clear, although the coding practice in class could've been organized better.
I think this course was structured very well. Each week coincided with a chapter of the required reading, and each week flowed well from one to the next.

Strengths: interesting topic to explore statistics through

Weaknesses: class is long and can be hard to get through

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Course worked very well online. Professor Meyers helped us debug frequently through screen share. I liked the breakout rooms for book discussion - helped us get closer as a group.
I think that this course was relatively well-adapted to facilitate virtual learning.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes -- this course is great if you are trying to get a grip on coding, to understand data analysis better, or if you want to see how you can apply data science to real-world fields like baseball (application courses are seemingly scarce in Yale's CS and S&DS departments, so this course is great).

Absolutely. All problems sets are in python so you get the opportunity to do quite a bit of coding. Additionally, Professor Meyers was incredibly accommodating and allows students to perform problem sets in either the Datascience or Pandas package. Overall, if you are someone who wants a more python focused data science class with a very thoughtful, committed professor, this is a great course for you to take.
Yes! I know how to answer my own questions about baseball now. And I learned much more about Python than I did in YData.

Take if you're interested in baseball or need the stats certificate. Taking the main Y-Data course is not necessary to take this course, and the material overlaps a lot with S&DS 230. With all that said, it's a great class.
Yes.
Yes, especially if youre a baseball fan.
Yes. Cool way to learn about baseball and Python together.
Yes! I really enjoyed this course even as someone who is not a huge baseball fan. I've wanted to learn python for a while and this was a great way to do so.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: N/A
